title: Jonah's Prayer of Deliverance
shortSummary: Jonah 2 records the prophet’s heartfelt prayer from inside the fish, expressing his distress, repentance, and trust in God's salvation. This chapter highlights God's mercy and power to save even in the most desperate circumstances.
timeline: c. 8th century BC - During the prophetic ministry of Jonah

keyCharacters.name: Jonah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who, after being swallowed by a great fish, prays to God from within the fish’s belly, expressing repentance and faith.

keyCharacters.name: The Fish
keyCharacters.description: The large sea creature that God commands to swallow Jonah and later to release him onto dry land.

definitions.definition: In this context, 'hell' (Hebrew: Sheol) refers to the realm of the dead or the depths of distress, not the final place of eternal punishment.
An offering made to God as an act of worship, thanksgiving, or atonement, symbolizing devotion and repentance.
God’s compassionate and forgiving nature, withholding deserved punishment and extending grace.
Promises made to God, often in times of distress, committing oneself to worship or obedience upon deliverance.

outline.heading: Jonah’s Prayer from the Fish’s Belly
outline.description: Jonah cries out to God in his distress, acknowledging his peril and expressing faith that God hears his prayer and has the power to save. His prayer reflects repentance and a renewed hope in God’s mercy.

outline.heading: Contrast Between the Wicked and the Penitent
outline.description: Jonah contrasts those who trust in falsehoods and abandon mercy with his own commitment to offer thanksgiving and fulfill his vows, affirming that salvation belongs to the LORD alone.

outline.heading: God’s Deliverance of Jonah
outline.description: God commands the fish to release Jonah, demonstrating His sovereign power to save and restore those who repent and call upon Him.

application: In times of distress, believers should turn to God in prayer, trusting that He hears and responds to their cries.
Repentance and faith in God’s mercy are essential for experiencing His salvation and deliverance.
Keep your promises to God and offer thanksgiving for His faithfulness in answering prayer.
Remember that salvation is always from the LORD, and rely on Him rather than on false hopes or worldly solutions.

keyVerses.text: And said, I cried by reason of mine affliction unto the LORD, and he heard me; out of the belly of hell cried I, and thou heardest my voice.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows Jonah’s recognition that God hears the prayers of the repentant even in the depths of despair.

keyVerses.text: But I will sacrifice unto thee with the voice of thanksgiving; I will pay that that I have vowed. Salvation is of the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: Jonah declares his commitment to worship God and affirms the fundamental truth that salvation comes only from the LORD.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD spake unto the fish, and it vomited out Jonah upon the dry land.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s sovereign power to deliver and restore those who call upon Him in repentance.
